ticket.tag: 2-3-stable edge migrate patch rake ruby1.9.2 schema
ticket.title: Ruby 1.9.2 compat: add to_str to ColumnDefinition
ticket.original-body:
rake db:migrate doesn't work on Ruby 1.9.2 because Array#* uses to_str instead of to_s to join values since Ruby 1.9.2.
Attached a patch to add to_str to ColumnDefinition which applies to master and 2-3-stable.
ticket.latest-body:

Attached a patch to add to_str to ColumnDefinition which applies to master and 2-3-stable.

version.title: Ruby 1.9.2 compat: add to_str to ColumnDefinition

version.body:
But ColumnDefinition really is not string-like. Is using to_str appropriate?
Perhaps we should not use Array#* instead.
version.body-html:
But ColumnDefinition really is not string-like. Is using to_str appropriate?

Perhaps we should not use Array#* instead.

Updated the patch not to use to_str nor to_s.

version.title: Ruby 1.9.2 compat: add to_str to ColumnDefinition

version.body:
I checked on Ruby 1.9.2 and it appears to still use to_s. Did I miss this change? 
$ ruby19 -v
ruby 1.9.2dev (2009-08-06) [i386-darwin9.7.0]
$ irb19
>> class Foo; def to_s; 'bar' end end
=> nil
>> [Foo.new, Foo.new] * ' '
=> "bar bar"
version.body-html:
I checked on Ruby 1.9.2 and it appears to still use to_s. Did I miss this change?

$ ruby19 -v
ruby 1.9.2dev (2009-08-06) [i386-darwin9.7.0]
$ irb19
>> class Foo; def to_s; 'bar' end end
=> nil
>> [Foo.new, Foo.new] * ' '
=> "bar bar"

version.title: Ruby 1.9.2 compat: add to_str to ColumnDefinition

version.body:
Is something redefined in Struct? (ColumnDefinition is a Struct)
$ irb --prompt=simple >> RUBY_DESCRIPTION => "ruby 1.9.2dev (2009-07-31 trunk 24341) [i386-darwin9.7.0]" >> X = Class.new => X >> [X.new, X.new] * '--' => "#<X:0x2e0f04>--#<X:0x2e0ec8>" >> Y = Struct.new(:a, :b) => Y >> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "------" # *3* separators ?? >> class Y; def to_s; 'hi!'; end; end => nil >> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "------" >> class Y; def to_str; 'hola!'; end; end => nil >> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "hola!--hola!"
version.body-html:
Is something redefined in Struct? (ColumnDefinition is a Struct)

$ irb --prompt=simple

RUBY_DESCRIPTION => "ruby 1.9.2dev (2009-07-31 trunk 24341) [i386-darwin9.7.0]" X = Class.new => X [X.new, X.new] * '--' => "#<X:0x2e0f04>--#<X:0x2e0ec8>" Y = Struct.new(:a, :b) => Y [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "------" # 3 separators ?? class Y; def to_s; 'hi!'; end; end => nil [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "------" class Y; def to_str; 'hola!'; end; end => nil [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "hola!--hola!"

version.body:
bah. Hope this formats correctly.
$ irb --prompt=simple >> RUBY_DESCRIPTION => "ruby 1.9.2dev (2009-07-31 trunk 24341) [i386-darwin9.7.0]" >> X = Class.new => X >> [X.new, X.new] * '--' => "#<X:0x2e0f04>--#<X:0x2e0ec8>" >> Y = Struct.new(:a, :b) => Y >> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "------" >> class Y; def to_s; 'hi!'; end; end => nil >> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "------" >> class Y; def to_str; 'hola!'; end; end => nil >> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--' => "hola!--hola!"
version.body-html:
bah. Hope this formats correctly.

$ irb --prompt=simple
>> RUBY_DESCRIPTION
=> "ruby 1.9.2dev (2009-07-31 trunk 24341) [i386-darwin9.7.0]"
>> X = Class.new
=> X
>> [X.new, X.new] * '--'
=> "#<X:0x2e0f04>--#<X:0x2e0ec8>"
>> Y = Struct.new(:a, :b)
=> Y
>> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--'
=> "------"
>> class Y; def to_s; 'hi!'; end; end
=> nil
>> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--'
=> "------"
>> class Y; def to_str; 'hola!'; end; end
=> nil
>> [Y.new, Y.new] * '--'
=> "hola!--hola!"
version.tag: 2-3-stable edge migrate patch rake ruby1.9.2 schema
version.title: Ruby 1.9.2 compat: add to_str to ColumnDefinition

version.body:
Yes, it's because of Struct#to_a 

>> Bar = Struct.new(:a, :b)
=> Bar
>> bars = [Bar.new('1', '2'), Bar.new('3', '4')]
=> [#<struct Bar a="1", b="2">, #<struct Bar a="3", b="4">]
>> bars * '--'
=> "1--2--3--4"
>> class Bar; def to_s; 'foo' end end
=> nil
>> bars * '--'
=> "1--2--3--4"
>> class Bar; undef_method :to_a end
=> Bar
>> bars * '--'
=> "#<struct Bar a=\"1\", b=\"2\">--#<struct Bar a=\"3\", b=\"4\">"
>> class Bar; def to_str; 'foo' end end
=> nil
>> bars * '--'
=> "foo--foo"
To see why, check ary_join_1: 

          default:
            tmp = rb_check_string_type(val);
            if (!NIL_P(tmp)) {
                val = tmp;
                goto str_join;
            }
            tmp = rb_check_convert_type(val, T_ARRAY, "Array", "to_a");
            if (!NIL_P(tmp)) {
                obj = val;
                val = tmp;
                goto ary_join;
            }
rb_check_convert_type catches Struct since it's T_DATA, so it's incorrectly treated as joining a recursive array. I think this is a Ruby bug.
version.body-html:
Yes, it's because of Struct#to_a


>> Bar = Struct.new(:a, :b)
=> Bar
>> bars = [Bar.new('1', '2'), Bar.new('3', '4')]
=> [#<struct Bar a="1", b="2">, #<struct Bar a="3", b="4">]
>> bars * '--'
=> "1--2--3--4"
>> class Bar; def to_s; 'foo' end end
=> nil
>> bars * '--'
=> "1--2--3--4"
>> class Bar; undef_method :to_a end
=> Bar
>> bars * '--'
=> "#<struct Bar a=\"1\", b=\"2\">--#<struct Bar a=\"3\", b=\"4\">"
>> class Bar; def to_str; 'foo' end end
=> nil
>> bars * '--'
=> "foo--foo"

To see why, check ary_join_1:


          default:
            tmp = rb_check_string_type(val);
            if (!NIL_P(tmp)) {
                val = tmp;
                goto str_join;
            }
            tmp = rb_check_convert_type(val, T_ARRAY, "Array", "to_a");
            if (!NIL_P(tmp)) {
                obj = val;
                val = tmp;
                goto ary_join;
            }

rb_check_convert_type catches Struct since it's T_DATA, so it's incorrectly treated as joining a recursive array.

I think this is a Ruby bug.
version.tag: 2-3-stable edge migrate patch rake ruby1.9.2 schema
version.title: Ruby 1.9.2 compat: add to_str to ColumnDefinition

version.body:
Actually, it's intentional: 
commit d32b853e4502e385372e5ae45503290df824518e
Author: matz 
Date:   Fri Jul 3 18:14:33 2009 +0000

    * enum.c (enum_join): add Enumerable#join.
    
    * array.c (ary_join_1): recursive join for Enumerators (and
      objects with #to_a).
    
    * array.c (rb_ary_join): performance tune.
    
    git-svn-id: http://svn.ruby-lang.org/repos/ruby/trunk@23951 b2dd03c8-39d4-4d8f-98ff-823fe69b080e
version.body-html:
Actually, it's intentional:

commit d32b853e4502e385372e5ae45503290df824518e
Author: matz 
Date:   Fri Jul 3 18:14:33 2009 +0000

    * enum.c (enum_join): add Enumerable#join.
    
    * array.c (ary_join_1): recursive join for Enumerators (and
      objects with #to_a).
    
    * array.c (rb_ary_join): performance tune.
    
    git-svn-id: http://svn.ruby-lang.org/repos/ruby/trunk@23951 b2dd03c8-39d4-4d8f-98ff-823fe69b080e

version.title: Ruby 1.9.2 compat: add to_str to ColumnDefinition

version.body:
Oops, I cut and pasted too much. 

>> class Bar; undef_method :to_a end
=> Bar
>> bars * '--'
=> "#<struct Bar a=\"1\", b=\"2\">--#<struct Bar a=\"3\", b=\"4\">"
above actually results in "foo--foo" since to_s is defined.
version.body-html:
Oops, I cut and pasted too much.


>> class Bar; undef_method :to_a end
=> Bar
>> bars * '--'
=> "#<struct Bar a=\"1\", b=\"2\">--#<struct Bar a=\"3\", b=\"4\">"

above actually results in "foo--foo" since to_s is defined.

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
